reviewText:
Early Access Review

Full Video Review: http://youtu.be/7XqZ-8EKoDg

++Best voxel based building system hands down. Ability to combine pieces gives buildings extremely high customizability and sleek ergonomics
+Dynamic destruction and advanced physics engine make destroying things just as fun as building them
+Creation of medieval inventions such as catapults, drawbridges, elevators, and whatever else you can come up with.
+Modding and workshop support for sharing creations

--Complex worlds and complex destruction cause massive lag, even on higher end machines
-No mode outside of creation yet, survival still a ways off
-No multiplayer as of yet
-Some types of contraptions are buggy and can break themselves

If you are into voxel creation games and you can deal with some optimization and minor structural integrity bugs you will have a blast with Medieval Engineers. If you are more into survival and PvP hold off until they add multiplayer and survival, because the building system will perfectly compliment that kind of gameplay.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Mediveal Engineers Survival Mode (currently):
It's a little like trying to build a nice model.

But you have to make a trip into the woods for each piece.

And once you get all your pieces on the table, the model might randomly decide to explode, killing you and your dog.

And while you're focused on building your model, a group of soccer hooligans show up, hold you down, and start punching you in the ♥♥♥♥ until you die.

And then you respawn at your bed, and go on a rampage, murdering everyone in your neighborhood.


Creative Mode:
You're Doctor Manhattan, floating around in the Alps, building Gondor.

Sometimes it blows up too. May or may not be your fault.



In short: it's totally worth it. Be sure to bring friends, and save often.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Please note this review is dated during the Early Access of this game and is subject to change I will do my best to update it when I see fit.

Medieval Engineers is a great building game with a ton of promise. I've never personally experience a better voxel system for quick and intuitive building. The game makes creation extremely easy and with the dynamic destruction and physics of it's engine it makes even mistakes or intentional destruction beautiful. On that note this game is very process intensive, demolishing huge castles will lagg even the best of PC's and in it's current build I have crashed quite often. That being said the act of building is spot on and in my honest opinion a very solid base for pretty much ensuring this will be a successful Early Access title. The game needs more content, that's a given, you are limited to what you can build because of lacking tools especially in the spring and rope territory. But with it's unique voxel construction system you can build blocks inside of blocks so if you're creative you can make some absolutely wild stuff in this early build. Be careful though the game does have a very decent structure system and if you don't build your castles with weight in mind they definitely can come tumbling down.

Overall in it's current build I give it 7/10 but with updates to the game engine (latency), added materials, multiplayer enabled and survival mode implemented I can seriously see this game being in the high 9s.

I don't want to be intrusive with videos but I am makign a series breifly overviewing a lot of the games core mechanics you can watch any at your viewing pleasure.

Building Basics
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=77Q5GlYA8oU&list=PLEngsjAeWQXinqF-wZBR8gFmRjwYamjpx

Destruction
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LYrGxt1rlOA&index=2&list=PLEngsjAeWQXinqF-wZBR8gFmRjwYamjpx

Siege Equipment
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NhnoJWrHkuI&list=PLEngsjAeWQXinqF-wZBR8gFmRjwYamjpx&index=3

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While I have played quite a few hours into Medieval Engineers, I cannot recommend it at its current state. I cannot really mention survival mode as being positive or negative. I honestly did not see the point of adding the mode this early into development.
I love building castles in any game. Medieval Engineers takes the cake. I have made large and small castles, both with little hidden tunnels and rooms. The possibilities are endless. The building mechanics can be a little difficult if you have never played Space Engineers. The system is almost the same as the system in Space Engineers. Building physics, oh my building physics. The first time a bridge collapsed, I didn't through a fit, I went nuts. The amount of destruction was... Glorious. I also like that there is an option to turn on to see the stresses on buildings. This definitely helps rather than flying blind. While I have not used multiplayer very often, I did play a few hours with some friends. Unfortunately, at the time, Castle Siege was not in the game. What we did do was using other gamemodes from other games. Things like; hide and go seek and TTT. This in itself was awesome. Wandering through castles wondering if someone was hiding in a hidden room was fantastic. The soundtrack blew me away when I first got the game. Then I felt like the same 4 songs were repeating over and over. So, for now, I have the music turned off.
Sadly, here comes the bubble popper. I cannot express my despair at this. This game desperately needs optimization. Sure, sure keep adding little weekly updates of doo dads but please, please, please give the users some damn optimization. I have a decent gaming rig and Medieval Engineers (borrowing the expression from my grandparents) runs like goose poop through a tin horn." I am currently running on the lowest graphical settings and I can barely go over 30 fps. The game appears to become slower with every "oooh a piece of candy update. Also
date: if some optimization does eventually happen
recommended: please DO NOT give Nvidia users special treatment. I feel like so many developers just optimize for Nvidia and call it finished. I suppose that is a rant for another day. Then there is a fog. If you watch videos from the developers and users alike
hoursPlayed: you will notice that there is this strange fuzziness and fog. I am not sure what to call it
voteText: but I hate it. I prefer games with crystal clarity
helpfulPercent: not "I smeared mayonnaise in my eyes
votesHelpful: some one help me." I also despise the sounds the developers used for fires. The sound would be okay if it wasn't so loud. I cannot walk through my castles without it sounding like someone started roasting weenies on a bon fire. If I could just remove that single sound from the game I would be incredibly happy.\nAll of this said
votesTotal:
I will still put more hours into the game. Perhaps a few hours here and there before the lag gives me a headache. If you can get the game for $10 USD or less (including the soundtrack) go for it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is an Early Access game, so I can only judge this game by its updates (frequency, value of the updates, etc).
Before I do this, I have to warn those who actually want to have tons of fun with this game:

This game is actually not really enjoyable at all (at least not for me). Game mechanics are broken, physics on self made war machines are bugged and sometimes your creation will just explode, even if you have no spring or something attached to it. Also controls are weird. So if you expect this to work as good as - lets say Besiege - you should wait a few more months. And then you should remember that Medieval Engineers is or will be more realistic than Besiege.

BUT Keen House Software, well known because of it's first 'Engineering'-game Space Engineers are updating really frequent with content updates and bugfixes. In the last week they fixed incredibly much and new content was also added to the game. And there are still huge updates for Space Engineers (planets confirmed, yayy!). So if you want to have a good game in the future, if you are aware this is an early alpha and if you want to test the (incredibly good) destruction engine, you should pick it up now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I like to go in blind, so I started out with in survival mode with everything at whatever defaults the devs thought best. Here's my experience so far:

I awoke in a rather picturesque field of grass and flowers next to a cart. I pushed the cart and it moved easily, which seemed like good news, but I'd save that for later. I immediately headed for a forest I saw in the distance as that looked like a good place to start my search for useful resources. Arriving at the edge of the forest I immediately grabbed the axe I had conveniently been provided and chopped down a tree. The tree fell on me and I died.

I awoke again next to my trusty cart and headed in a different direction. This time I wandered until I came across an abandoned house. It wasn't the most interesting thing I'd ever seen, so I wandered back toward the forest. Noticing my growing hunger, I looked around for food and saw an unsuspecting deer. I tried to get the deer. The deer ran away. I searched some more and found some mushrooms. At this point I was quite hungry so it seemed worth the risk. I ate the mushrooms which turned out to be nothing more than edible mushrooms.

I wandered back to the tree I had chopped down and tried to pick it up. Apparently a 175kg log wouldn't fit in my backpack, so I chopped it into smaller pieces and carried them back to a relatively level area in the field to start building some shelter.


The game is absolutely not done, and a cursory glance at the forums will show you a definite weak spot in project management, resulting in a somewhat unstructured and chaotic release cycle. To their credit, they specifically list Project Manager as an open position, so I think they're aware.

The bottom line is this game is fun in its current state, and promises much more. If you like survival, building, medieval times and being crushed by falling trees, this game is absolutely for you.

10/10 would be crushed again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Medieval Engineers is the prequel of the popular game Space Engineers. In the game, you play an engineer with the task of building a new castle for your feudal overlord.
After many plot twists and backstabs in this political scenario that makes Crusader Kings 2 look like Sesame Street, you must hide the last remaining Engineers in an abandoned mineshaft whereupon an elevator is required. After many failed attempts, the elevator develops conciousness and physics-defying controlled flight with you onboard and travels to the stars.
And then Space Engineers starts.

10/10 Would develop a self-councious medieval transmission system again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Update 4. march 2015: New patch today/yesterday introduces breakable ropes and rope hooks that can release a rope at a certain angle (perfect for making trebuchet siege weapons). The breakable ropes snap at contact with another block, a barbarian or the player. This is excellent news and gives a lot of possibilites! A great creative physics playground just got even better.

The ability to remove broken blocks automatically is also added and makes repairing a castle much easier. No more walking into broken blocks to push them out of the way in order to place a new block. Thank you Keen Software House!! Saves so much time when your ridiculously high princess tower" collapses for the third time!

Also added was the ability to switch between day and night in creative mode
date: so you can see your pretty castle with torches and other light sources in the dark. Very pretty! My dream castle became even more wonderful in the dark :-)\n\nThey also made a rudimentary survival mode that makes you die if you fall down too high or get stuff in your head (like blocks
recommended: barbarians clubs or artillery projectiles).\n\nSo far
hoursPlayed:
they are keeping their "patch every tuesday" promise. 11/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This isn't really a review, but a note to those looking to buy this game.

As of the release of this title, you only have Single Player Creative, you will not be able to play with friends just yet, nor is there any survival mode.

So unless you're very eager to mess around in Creative Mode, I would recommend that you wait until it is further developed.

The physics and destruction are a lot of fun, and for being so shortly after release I would say it's pretty decently optimized.

You can tell that it's still Space Engineers, which I think is a good thing. I think this game is very promising, but as I said, unless you're into creative mode and wanna get a early peek at what it's gonna be like - do not buy it.

If there was Multiplayer and Survival mode, then yes, I would highly recommend it. :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not recommending this early on, obviously my **OPINION** but I feel like there isn't much to do.
I understand that it is early access so it's more about getting everything to work rather than having things to do, but from the same developers of Space Engineers I just found it a bit meh.
Pros
Good Optimisation
Good Destruction
Nice Graphics
Good blocks currently in the game
Good Construction System

Cons
Not many blocks
Expensive early access game for the content.
Certain mechanisms will not work after relaunching the game - Locking up of contraptions - Etc.
Excessive destruction - It doesn't take much to destroy a solid stone block
Confusing to start with - No gradual way to ease the player into the game.

Hopes
I hold out hope purely because it's from the same people that have made space engineers, it's fun but at this current state it should be left until a few more blocks and systems have been added and any kinks worked out.

TL;DR
Good game, not much to do. Wait until there is more.
EDIT: 31/03/2015: It's getting better, but it's fairly slow. It's showing promise but I'd still say wait a bit.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Perhaps the most enjoyable sandbox I've played since Minecraft..for the 3 hours I managed to play it, at least.
The building mechanics are intuitive and for the most part easy to use, and the destruction engine is reminiscent of Red Faction: Guerrila. If you want to understand that last part, watch someones video on YouTube.
However, whilst I do recommend this game it is only in the hope that the developers will improve on this. The game is perhaps the most unoptimised I have ever played, with lag occuring almost every time you destroy something. The game also lacks a large number of objects to build with. It would be even better if it had a Besiege swing to it, with AI that actually moves, interacts etc.
My PC isn't the best, I will be using an i5 as of tomorrow, which may combat the problems with FPS drops during destruction, but what really is disappointing is I can no longer play the game. My graphics card does qualify above the recommended requirements, but now whenever I try to play the game I am given an error. After trying the troubleshoots people have come up with it still doesn't work, and I hope that the developers will get back to me with a solution. I do believe it is because my graphics card uses Nvidia's Kepler microarchitecture, which struggles to use DX11.1.

So, 7/10 in the hope that the developers grow this game, optimise it, and solve the issues people are having with DX11.1.#

Edit: 2 hours later, it's been fixed, I can now play. They've added multiplayer and sounds. Best game ever.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well, it's launch day and that means everyone who's been drooling over this game is rushing to buy it.  Myself included.  That said, there might be a few people out there with questions.  Hopefully this will answer them.

Medieval Engineers is an absolutely beautiful game.  Everything from the folliage to the map-edge backdrop is very well done.  The music is perfect, and brings you a true sense of that medieval feeling.  In addition the physics engine is the best I've seen in a building game.  This game is well worth the money.  That said, there are a few drawbacks to the current version of the game so I'm going to let you know what you'll be getting into.  Note:  This list ONLY applies to the EARLY ACCESS LAUNCH.  I have no doubt things will be updated in the coming days and months.  So here we go;

- No Survival Mode.
- No Multiplayer.
- Map size is limited, although Normal" is a pretty decent size.
- Very limited selection of parts.
- Building collapses can cause heavy lag.
- Heavy load times on map entry.
- Limited rotation of some parts.
- During building it feels too much like "Space Engineers"
recommended: do I recommend this game?  HELL YES!  That said
hoursPlayed: if you're on the fence about purchasing it I'd watch the updates for now.  Wait until more parts are added and survival mode + multiplayer is included.  That way you won't be disapointed with your purchase.\n\nOtherwise
voteText: if you can deal with the limited state of the current game and trust solely in the knowledge that it will be improved
helpfulPercent: BUY IT NOW!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Buying Early Access Games always leave me quite concerned. There are a lot of them that promise much and deliver very few, taking too long to finish or even being released without getting finished at all. But THAT'S NOT THE CASE with Medieval Engeneers.

There has been only a few months since this game has been released in Alpha and it is ABSOLUTELY ♥♥♥♥ING AWESOME already!!
Keen Software House (the Producers) also produce Space Engeneers and both games are very well built. They are constantly being updated, mostly in a weekly basis (with bug fixes in a daily basis), and problems are very rare.

Here goes a short synopse of what you get from this, yet brute but already quite refined, Diamond:

- You get to build amazing Medieval Structures of Stone, Wood and Iron from scratch.
- You can terraform the land, raise mountains, dig deep mines and build whatever you like upon it.
- Construction is made through a very cleaver system of Stackable Blocks, which sometimes can be overlaid in order to create even more awesome composite blocks.
- Blocks are affected by real Phisics. Weight, Height and Impact affect the blocks and they even crumble when overloaded.
- EVERYTHING IS DESTRUCTABLE! You can build large fortresses just to have a lot of fun destroying it later on. And destroying it isn't only realistic as hell, but it's also very very fun!!
- You can already build a wide variety of buildings (from tiny poor villager houses to might Castles and Citadels), and every week more and more blocks are released into the game.
- The game also provides easy access to even more blocks from Steam Workshop's independant developers.
- You can build not only fixed buildings, but also complex mechanisms like Lifts, Porticulis, Draw Bridges, Catapults, Onagers, Trebuchets, Balistas, Windmills, etc. AND THEY ACTUALLY WORK!!!

This game is Heaven for your Creativity and only the sky is the Limit.
I recommend this game, I recommend the producers and I also recommend buyinf it even on Early Access. If you liked to play with Legos when you were younger, you are sure to love it as much as I do.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've had plenty of fun with Space Engineers, and Medieval Engineers is basically that, but with actual physics and a Medieval theme (go figure).

Given the massive progress of Space Engineers, and this game being made by the same developers with their own dedicated team (as in not taken from the SE team) working on it, I'd say it's definitely worth picking up right now if you're willing to wait.

If you aren't, wait until the game gets multiplayer and survival mode. It will be more than worth the price of admission then.

Also, just in case you didn't read the store page, don't go into this game expecting it to be medieval Minecraft. With the structural integrity system this game has, you can't build the sort of fantastical structures you could in Minecraft. Hell, you probably won't even be able to build a small house properly on your first try. Yes, you can disable it, but why would you do that?

I understand it is in Early Alpha" therefore it still has its issues.  I have Space Engineers also and seeing how well that game has grown an advanced I would only expect this game to do also.  The level of game detail is great

the depth you have when building and creating machines is amazing.
If you enjoy Space Engineers / Minecraft style creative games then this is for you.  I think this game is just going to get bigger and better and may I dare to say might rival Minecraft if they push it in that direction.  Anyone sitting on the fence about this game should jump off and get it quick.
There are current system requirements to play the game that are quite high so please be sure to check it will run on your machine before you buy.  Also this is a "Early Alpha" game so be aware it has very minimal content other the creative mode but what is there is a lot to work with already.

So in closing I highly recommend this game
recommended: but do your homework about it before you make your final decision."

reviewText:
Early Access Review


About a year ago I hard about this game. I won't lie, I got super excited about it. In fact I got so excited I binge played Banished and Stronghold. I didn't want to get it yet because it was pre-alpha (very few pre-alpha games are good. Empyrion Galactic Survival is a good game and is in pre-alpha) and it would be too buggy.

In case you don't know about the game, ME is you and some friends in a giant pit surrounded by mountains with a forest smack dab in the center (at least on our map) and you have to bum rush for items like food and such. You build a castle and combat your others of the game and can build an army of peasent's to do your bidding. We never got far enough to see WHAT the peasents would do, however, as the game is now only in alpha and the many bugs left in the physics engine would kill the peasents. I want to say now: these guys are building from the ground up. They might be using unity or something, but I am still in awe at how complex this game actually is in it's early stages.

On to what I don't like here. As I said there are many physics bugs, however not so severe that if you get stuck in a crick in a hole you get shot into the atmosphere (this happens in 7 Days To Die, another good pre-alpha game). No, instead if you have your peasents doing generic things, like gather wood and stone, and have them flop it into a pile somewhere things have a tendency to slide wherever they want. EVERYthing on the map is a hill. You cannot go anywhere in the basin and not be climbing or going down something, Whether that is a bug in map generation or something, no clue. Because the items move around the AI trips over everything, including their own feet (which is really freaking funny to see). Bjorg and Helga can be hauling wood and stone while Ingvarad is organising wood, but then Bjorg hits Invar with a stick, nothing is actually no-collided in the engine, and then Bjorg, Invar, Helga, You, Half your castle, AND probably some trees are up in the atmosphere. Then some raiders run by and steal your ♥♥♥♥; did I mention that? Fun fact the raiders are no-collided but nothing else is. You can walk through them. WTF.

Next to that there is no tutorial. The game has been out a year and all you get is an obnoxious block of text that never goes away that says HIT F1 TO SEE SOME ♥♥♥♥" and then you have SEVEN PAGES OF KEYSTROKES to go through to learn how to build a wall. A freaking wall. Yeah you start out with some walls
date: but you have to figure this ♥♥♥♥ out like they did way back in 903. Now that I think about it that it kind of ingenius.....\n\nThis would be fixed if looking at stuff would say "Hit T to Pick Up" or "Hit C To Open Crafting Menu!" In fact
recommended: if they would fix the damn inventory system that would be cool. I like it; it actually reminds me of games like High Seas Trader (dos game from 1992/5) but jesus ♥♥♥♥ man

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Space Engineers set 200 years earlier...

Took me and my mate over 2 hours to try and construct just a tiny shelter in survival. After so much frustration (and hilarity at our own failure), we gave up.

Surprising how poor this game is compared to it's big brother (Space Engineers).

What's wrong with it? Well...
- You need to eat more frequently than Jabba the Hutt, else you starve and die.
- You can't move stones to build stuff, so you have to build where they fall.
- How the hell do you put a goddam roof on four walls!?
- Frequent random / weird deaths - Chops tree, walks into chopped wood, dies...wtf?
- Loads up new game, wanders into wood, finds random NPC running towards me. Gets killed by NPC with a club...eh!?
- Building anything is so fiddly it hurts
- Dreadful controls

It's like the dev's tried to do something different, got fed up and decided to concentrate on Space Engineers instead (which is a far better game)

May get better in the future, but for me it's a no" at the mo."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Keen Software delivers yet again redefining how we think of Creativity Sandboxes and Voxel games, and taking all the wonderment of building in Space, and slapping it on the ground. Coupled with this is the introduction of structural integrity, the ability to have two blocks occupying the same space, and an absolutely smashing soundtrack, Medieval Engineers, though presently unpolished, is rapidly shaping up to be the kind of game that many will rapidly learn to enjoy in a big way!

There's not much to do yet other than build, but every week, new content is coming out, and new tweaks to the engine to make everything work that much better!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I do not like the idea of writing negative reviews on games. However, I cannot recommend this title in its present state. This one has been out for some time, and it is still very poorly allocated. The memory allocation makes the game almost impossible to run. I have a GTX970 video card, and a 4690 Intel processor, as well as 8G of ram. The game is not running worth a darn on it. It continually freezes up (usually after every single block placement while building), and then crashes to desktop, saying that there is sufficient memory for all the tasks running. The only things running is the Steam ap and the game. When the problem is posted on the discussion page, the devs do not respond. The only response I have seen is the statement that the individual's computer is not powerful enough to play the game. And this for a fairly high-end rig.

The construction inventory, to be fair, is fairly extensive. However, it lacks some fairly vital and basic items. For instance, you can place statues around the castle courtyard, but there are no doors of any kind. No drawbridges, nothing. So either you cannot leave the keep, or the enemies can just walk in. I can see this oversight for a short while, but for any length of time it is pretty game breaking.

As a multiplayer game it has some serious potential down the road, provided the devs actually (eventually) respond to, and address the issues in-game. But that time has not yet arrived. And as long as they ignore these legitimate concerns from their customers, the game is still fairly unplayable. As a single-player game, which the store page insists that it is, there is nothing to do but to build the architecture. No serious NPC's exist or are slated to ever exist as far as I can tell. That is not all bad. As a castle-building simulator, it could be fun for some people, and I would eventually be willing to recommend it at that time, provided the problems are addressed.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFinally, a piece of user-friendly software puts historical recreation right into everyone's grasp! In addition to being a fun sandbox/world-builder, Medieval Engineers is an extremely powerful engine for re-creating history. Even in its early-release Alpha stage, it already offers so much. You can build a town that's only known now in ruins & stories, and then explore it -- house by house, room by room. Attack it, defend it, live in it for a while. Team up with modders to populate your site with whatever art & artefacts & design styles you want. Whatever you wish! The future of gaming is bright with this program.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The thing to remember about this game is that it is early access. And oh, how early access it truly is.

In its current form (I write this in April 2015, just after the addition of deer AI), I would not reccomend getting this game. At all. There are just so many bugs, lag issues and imperfections. I have faith they will be fixed as the game development progresses, but right now, it's horrific.

And one thing stands out above all else.

The game lags, all the time. Every time anything is hit by a projectile, or otherwise damaged by other means, the game freezes. And I don't want to hear any crap from people saying it's about system requirements; I have every single aspect of the reccomended PC specifications fulfilled, and it still behaves this way. You would have to hack into the Pentagon and use their supercomputers to run this game for it to be smooth, and even then it'd probably freeze every now and then.

Oh, and the loading times. Good lord. It can take up to 3 minutes to load a level. Again, i'm sure this will be abbreviated by various adjustments to the physics engine and whatnot, but good god. Lord have mercy on the person who tries to open the replica of AC2's Monteriggioni someone made.

I feel this game has tremendous potential, and will mature into a good, entertaining experience given time, but in its current form, I do not reccomend you pay £15 to play the lagfest that is April 2015's Medieval Engineers.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

===EARLY ACCESS REVIEW===
This review is from an EARLY ACCESS STATE and may not be valid in the future.

I first purchased this game when it had just come out on Steam. It was wonderful at that point, had a lot of promise.
Unfortunately, I couldn't run it very well on my dual-core with 4GB of RAM, and r9-270x.

Fast forward to now - I run an i5, 12GB of RAM, and the same 270x, and the game runs massively worse.
When I first ran this game at release, I ran it on max settings at ~45fps, now with my upgraded computer I'm lucky to pull off 20fps at LOWEST settings at the same resolution. There are massive bugs (Floating buildings, etc) that still exist that have existed since day 1, and in it's current unlplayable state I definitely cannot recommend this unoptimized, buggy game.

Sure maybe if you have a 5930k, 16gb of RAM and a 980 ti you can get 50fps, but is that worth it to run this little thing?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Short review-amazing.  Well worth 20 bucks if you enjoy building castles.

Long Review-
Pros
Hard game to stop playing.  There is always one more build to attempt and one more looky-loo at your creation.  After spending 3-4 hours messing around, learing the controls, I have been putting together an imense mountain castle that includes a drawbridge, portculi, dozens of towers, houses, and catapults.  It is easy to get lost in your work while hours pass by.  The graphics are beautiful, and on my new Alienware, I see the grass and trees sway in the breeze.  I get the same feeling playing this game that I got as a kid playing with legos nonstop, oblivious to the world.
But, there are a few problems that can be frustrating.
It's Alpha.  There is clunkiness to the controls, especially in clearing debris.
As others have mentioned, the buildings you constuct need to be over-engineered or they will tumble down.  There is a lack of variety of materials to flesh out your castle: a bed, table, dresser, and a chair is all you get for now.
Roofs can be very anoying to place correctly and if you misplace, you often delete the walls underneath in addition to the section of roof.
You also have only a half a dozen maps to choose from, none of which are overly large.  There is no water as of yet, so no moats.  Smoothing terrain is perhaps the most frustrating part of the game for me so far.  Instead of pushing down on terrain, you add up.  The controls are clunky, awkward, and no way to take away or delete terrain.  No food, crops, animals, resources, blacksmithing, or fine crafting of any type.
Flying can test your nerves as well.  Gravity doesn't exist if flying mode, so inertia sends you at mach 1 with just a touch of the controls.  You often need to be in the perfect spot to place a block, and the inertia controls require fine little pushes in the direction you want to travel in.  Plus, you are invulnerable and if you send yourself flying into a wall, if often comes tumbling down as cuss words tumble out of your mouth.
You can't name saved games, which can be anoying and load times can be long.  Finally, my last gripe is copying and pasting.  Currently, you copy everything already created.  So, let's say your castle is rocking, but you want to add some catapults.  You are forced to save, restart a new game, create your catapult, copy, exit game, and finally go back to your saved castle to plop and paste the weapons.
But, and I can't stress this enough, the game is very adicting.  For an Alpha, it's more than playable and it should only get better with more features being brought in.  Multiplayer could be a blast, as long as they toughen up the integrity of your creations or battles could be very very quick.  Overall, two fat thumbs up!

The game is fun and highly functioning, but there are certain aspects of the mechanics in the game which I would really like to see be changed. At the time of this review the follow mechanical problems exist:
When trying to build a circular tower, you cannot build a staircase within it because the staircase... touches...?... the walls.

You cannot build things directly on top of wooden platforms, instead the object you place on the wooden platform is elevated a few centimeters above it.

I have only briefly played this game and therefore these are the only things that have disrupted my game play. So far I have yet to see a bug, although controlling the character both in first person, third person and free mode is rather awkward. The graphics are very nice, it runs smoothly but I would like to see the loading time decreased significantally. I just recently read some of the negative reviews and I have to say, PLEASE remember that this is an ALPHA GAME. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Its minecraft for adults. Sort of. It plays alot like space engineers, which is a good thing, but it it has the creative factor that minecraft used to have. Its incomplete, its got some bugs, especially in block rotation and placement. You also cant delete debris yet, but there are ways around this. And structural integrity is a great feature, If you build like you might, in say minecraft or even space engineers, the game will punish you. you have to think ahead, what's going to need support, will x block be strong enough, etc. Its like playing with your cat, one moment everything is great, all is well, but then you do just the wrong thing and your getting bitten or clawed. but you don't mind, you keep on playing, because just like your cat, Medieval Engineers is just too lovable to stop playing, even if it does leave you cut and bleeding.

As far as debris is concerned there are two ways of dealing with it. One is to wait for them to delete themselves after a few minutes, but this wont get rid of blocks still intact enough to count are a full block but have come loose. Alternatly you can start a game, then save and go back to the main menu, go to load the save, but instead of loading your save go to edit settings and set the debris limit to 0. Blocks will still break and loose blocks will still fall, and poorly built structures will still colapse. But, there will be no anoying little debris that you can't delete with a right click. Beyond that, everything else is straight forward.

Buy it now while its on beta discount, you wont regret it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Long story short, wait until this game is fully released or at least into a beta before buying it. It was a fantastic game when it first came out but the amount of bugs it currently has will make you regret spending the money.

I'll preface this by saying that I was super excited to get this game when it first became available. As soon as I could I was playing it and I was amazed how well it worked for an alpha. At first there were very minor issues and bugs but overall the game was very playable, it was just a little lacking in features.

Then they started to pander to the people demanding a survival mode and multiplayer (before the underlying systems were fully there). The result? More bugs than you'd find in a hoarder's house.

Now I keep having the game just display blinding white, blocks that refuse to fit together like they had before, and control issues. It seems every update they add just makes things worse. Hell, most updates seem to be them trying to make multiplayer function more than trying to get the base game working.

Call me crazy but multiplayer needs to be dealt with after the basic functions are all there. Otherwise you have a completely unplayable game rather than just a limited one.

The problems Keen had with Space Engineers got resolved and I have no worries that Medieval Engineers will end up working. At the moment though, they are trying to do too much so you need to wait until the game can be finished so save yourself the headaches of wanting to play the game, but quitting because of the bugs.

I used to spend hours building cities and castles, now I avoid the game. I come back to it every once in a while but right now, it’s best to just not play it.

The videos you see were how the game played on original release. Literally, what you see in the videos they show you was how the game looked and worked in April 2015. If you want to see how Medieval Engineers works now, open word, zoom in 250% and stare at the white screen. That’ll be the current medieval engineers status and playability.

If you read this, buy the game, then leave a bad review because of bugs, just know satan has a very special place for your kind.

Overall, buy this game when it is fully released.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Medieval Engineers is in its early stages as I write this review.

Have you ever played block building games and felt the need to place foundations and build buttress, even though the game physics don't require it? Ever looked at a floating building with despair?

Then THIS is the game for you. Composite building and structural integrity mean you can build a realistic building where the design matters far more than in any other game of this kind.

I have clocked quite a few hours on this so far, and I can see myself whiling away a good chunk of my spare time here. I love the way you can build structures from deep basements to towering watchtowers that will collapse if I do it wrong!

Don't get me wrong, the physics aren't too punishing. You won't have your buildings falling apart every five minutes. It's just a relief to build structural supports where they actually have an effect.

The potential of this game has only just begun to be realized. I would recommend this to anyone who enjoys building. Also, to anyone who loves to destroy and test the strength of a tower.

[Addition] After a couple of months, I do find a degree of frustration with this game. Lag and frame drop are a very real issue everytime you know down a building. As I see much of the fun of this game in the destruction of what I build, this has become a real disappointment. I also love the idea of playing multiplayer, and running through a building my friend is destroying. Again though, lag is intense when destroying things, making this an almost unplayable feature.

It is my hope that this game will improve, but it might be worth waiting a while.

Early Access Review

The great feature of a physic that punishes bad engineering makes the game in my opinion a one of a kind medieval sandboxgame. reviewText:
Early Access Review

In its current state as of May 1st, 2015 the game is not much more then a couple of building blocks and terrain manipulation, as well as downloading other maps and exploring them. This itself is fun for a couple hours, but if you've played creation games you've done this before. The thing that sets this apart currently is the destruction which is immensely satisfying!

Buying this in its current state (as of this writing) is for helping the developers and taking their word on this game becoming something greater. I trust them which is why I recommend this, their work on Space Engineers is great and this game has a lot of promise.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have played a couple of hours of the game, BUT! The game right now is small, so I can allready take a solid review.
When I firstly launched the world, I felt like I have just appeared in the Medieval Era. The nicest medieval music and nice grassy plain met me with happiness and temptation. Then, turning left 135 degrees, I saw a house. I walked to it and sat inside, feeling really cozy. Although, then I saw big projectile in my belt. Of course, it is really obvious what to do. I saw how to control those in a really friendly presented tutorial. So, I walked out from that cozy 15th century house and picked up my projectile and BOOOM. The house is to the ground. Great havoc-ish damage physics - KSH always deals with those damage physics, in all their recent games.
Okay, I wanted to build a castle like this Neuschwanstein one. I found a mountain, terraformed a bit of ground for the keep and started building. I made a nice guard tower, which fromed so SOFTLY and INTUITIVE, which I can't say for some games, even, sometimes, Space Engineers. I copied the tower, although, it took me a big bite of my time to mess around with copying and pasting it. I couldn't rotate it. Although, I am going to close my eyes on ot - it's a magnificent alpha.
So, I saw another problem - maybe I am doing something wrong, or don't know how to do it. But I built my towers sideways to the voxel grid". I would need to build my walls the wacked way. *Sadface:(*

So

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Though this is in its very first stage pretty much this game already looks great and I can already tell this is going to be a big hit.

Pros
+Nice looking terrain and scenery
+Realistic physics
+Open for modding/workshop
+Epic music
+Lots more planned to be added

Cons
-Not that many blocks at the moment
-Needs to be optimized
-I am waiting on that survival mode ;)

Though keep in mind it has just been released and the developers are currently working hard at the game so I would recommend it for sure in a little bit of time.

P.S. You can throw ♥♥♥♥ing rocks at the castle and other crappy stuff in the workshop.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Overall, nice early accesss.

Pros:
-Works (I'm looking at you, ubisoft)
-Structural integrity is damn near beautiful
-nice looking
-replay value is seemingly endless
-building mechanics are good for an early access

Cons:
-sluggish menu
-loading time is pretty long (dependant on map size)
-rubble, rubble everywhere xD

------------------------------------------------------------------

I built for an hour until a beam snapped. Seeing that it was unfixable, I released a barrage of cannonballs and blew up my creation. once i found out that you could make the balls hit harder by holding m1, I was building things just so I could destroy them. 9/10

If you've got  15 bucks laying around. I'd be sure to pick it up! :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Keen Software House has come crashing down to Earth, it seems. Hot off the heels of their success with Space Engineers, the studio has taken a decidedly different approach to its next game. Yes, they’ve swapped the dark, lonely nothingness of outer space for the green and pleasant fields on Terra Firma. And whilst the core gameplay of Medieval Engineers is, in essence, no different from Space Engineers – build stuff, destroy stuff – it goes that extra mile to engross you in its twee setting. Medieval Engineers, like Space Engineers before it, launched as an Early Access title with a solid amount of content, and whilst its current incarnation only lets you build stuff just to knock it down, it gives an exciting glimpse at the possible shape the game might take in the future.

Before you can indulge in senseless destruction you’ve got to build something first and, even at this early stage, the creation tools on offer are surprisingly slick. You can choose from a different number of fields to start out in, be it a rocky hill terrain, or a plain with a castle town already in it. Building your own castles using the various building blocks available to you is a cinch, and the auto-snap grid means that you will line everything up correctly – almost every time! I say “almost” because, at present it can be a real pain the undersatchel to line up floor panels. That’s before I have even touched on the terraforming tools.

So, you’ve started building that ridiculously oversized mountain fortress and want to even out the ground a little, well it isn’t  going to be that easy. Terraforming, in theory, should be easy: you pick your brush shape, give it a width, height and depth, and can set about adding or subtracting ground blocks to the scene. There’s a bit of an art to it though, meaning you need a steady hand to keep things smooth – otherwise you end up with ground that has the texture of artex. Indeed, my inability to use the tool effectively saw me creating underground caverns that had an eerily beautiful quality to them, but I couldn’t get out! Hopefully, future releases will see these tools tweaked a bit for people like myself (idiots, basically).


You needn’t build alone, either! Get a buddy or two in on the action and you’ll be up and running with a serviceable castle in no time; the system really is just that astonishingly easy to use. Think of it like minecraft where each block looks different and has different properties – except they aren’t cubes, of course. There are all sorts of different blocks at your disposal, from round-edged  walls for turrets, battlement attachments, and windmill blades for the show-offs.

Humans will be human and it’s in our nature to tear down and destroy, and Medieval Engineers has you well covered in that department. Technical dunces like myself can equip small and large cannonballs to their hotbar and let rip a volley of shots on their structures, watching them crumble to the ground in a cloud of smoke and dust. There’s a perverse pleasure to be had in seeing your time-consuming efforts reduced to nought but rubble within a few minutes,  a feeling which is amplified by the warming celtic soundtrack that plays throughout. It’s a highly incongruous matchup, but also very enjoyable. You can further amplify the destruction by kicking your map’s maximum fracture pieces all the way to the top – your PC won’t thank you for it, but it sure as hell looks amazing! If you have the technical cojones to create catapults, trebuchets and other machines of war you can also set your mind free to think up the most dastardly creations it can. When you are done you can upload them to the Steam Workshop for others to enjoy – a feature that will no doubt become inundated with cool items I only wish I had the skills to create.


There is so much untapped potential waiting to come out of Medieval Engineers that it’s difficult to see what form the final game will take. Keen have recently released an update featuring barbarians so who knows, maybe we will see a full-on medieval war simulator, with massive castle-vs-castle battles? I’ll see you all there when I manage to get out of this damn hole!
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Disclosure: Preview key provided by Keen. Original review available at: http://criticalindiegamer.com/2015/02/medieval-engineers-preview-pc/

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Yes, I would recomment this game myself. You have to realize though:
1) This is still an Early Access game. Some of the features you EXPECT in this game, may not be applied yet.
2) It came out not too long ago. You have to give it time before you negatively affect the reviews.

As of now, There isnt much to do, but master the games mechanics and learn how to build. You can destroy things, and as of yesterday i believe, You are able to spawn barbarians to do the destroying for you.

I wouldn't recommend this game if it wasnt for one slight detail.

The developers are active. They are informing the community and are searching for ways to improve the game. Great people, and i do not believe they would abandon a game that was already advanced into early access. Especially since they can see the potential. We all have seen games where the devs havent notified the community in months. No updates in a year or so, and all the updates they do are just average bug fixes. I can tell you from my time playing Space Engineers (SE) That this is not the case.

Note: Please also take into account that they are still working forward in SE. They applied workshop for us to keep ourselves entertained so they can have time to get what they need done, done. It's not a fast process.
I will keep updating this as time moves along, as of right now the question is simple:

Do you want to be part of a growing, excited community and support the devs?

*UPDATE* 3/10/2015

Finally added some new things! They now added barbarians, a survival setting where barbarians will attack your king statue every certain amount of minutes! Im really excited about this update. however, there are still many glitches.

Like turning into jesus after throwing a cannonball.
Freeze Framing in midair.
Along with, barbarians attacking eachother instead of the statue,
Barbarians throwing cannon balls BACK AT YOU (kobe),
and The whole building youre in collapsing from one hit. lol.

The glitches so far are very amusing. That is why i still suggest this game.

I will keep updates as the game goes on.

*UPDATE*  3/25/2015

They finally!! Added!!! Ragdolls!!! You now have a day and night cycle. Which makes the survival more a bit more interesting. Along with that you know have pick axes, and other hand tools such as the torch and mace for defense.

I have yet to try the full experience for the survival mode, for ive been very busy, as soon as i do i will update again. I'm hoping they added material requirments in survival mode to build with. Either way this game keeps getting better and better.

The developers are cracking down hard on this game. However the only MAJOR con that i can see in this game so far, (well besides the things they havent added yet) Is the ability to spawn bots. Yes, this is an early access game and they probably dont have the patches to support alot of bots walking around the world at this time but i feel if you want to crash your game? crash it. lol. Right now you are only able to spawn 4 to 5 barbarians and and 3 peasants. Peasants will stockpile your ammo crates. Where they stockpile them at though is not under your control at this time.

Example:
I buillt a Practical castle. 4 walls. Each corner had a rotating catauplt on it. Outside I build a couple houses for scenery. Inside the castle were:
Barracks
A main hall
Mess hall
Courtyard
Statue
Garden
and War room. along with an extra hidden passage out. (i havent yet mastered the art of digging underground so it was just a doorway hidden by bushes and trees.
I was launching my catapults for fun, and decided to test out the peasants. I noticed he took the ammo off of my catapult head every time i spawned one before i could launch it. This took my interest. I followed this young fellow of which i named jerry. I followed him far and wide. Out of the reaches of my castle. Through the hidden passage. Far into the reaches of the forests. Passed the hills. The he stopped. only for a second. Dropped the rock. Turned around and ran back to the castle. -_-
I stayed put trying to figure out why he dropped the rock there. I waited. He came back with another rock. Dropped it in the same place.
To speed things up, i spawned in 2 more peasants. To which they continued to fight over where the rocks would be placed. one would pick it up. walk over five feet and drop it. to which the other would pick it up and run another five feet and drop it. This continued until the other one came back with YET ANOTHER rock.... At which time they killed eachother by picking it up (and i guess glitching) And causing two of them to ragdoll.

Other than that, yes i recommend this game. The devs are hammering down to add new parts. In the end it will truly be an amazing game.

If you played and liked Space Engineers, you should get this game.
If you don't have Space Engineers, you should get this game and then get Space Engineers.
If you like Minecraft, get this game.
If you like games in general, get this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A beautiful little game.

Staying true to their words Keen are an excellent developer who don't ever seem to miss a beat. While it is early access and only just released, meaning theres a lot of work down the line to wait for, the game is still in a playable and fun state; You'll find yourself eagerly awaiting every Thursday while already being able to build dominating castles, underground cities, inventions and catapults and soon to be more.

On top of that, the development of Space Engineers alongside Medieval is an exciting prospect, as they both benefit one another directly. This is one of the few early access games I can buy into confidently and be sure I'm going to get three times my money back from.

Just... be careful around the physics.
While fun, they are in development, so things break where they shouldn't - but thats the game teething just like Space Engineers did.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let's get this out of the way: This game is not even remotely close to being in a state that meets the expectations you might have after watching the video trailers. You are extremely limited in what you can do at this time.

Essentially, you only have 'creative mode' available to you at this moment, but if Keen updates this with the same pacing and quality of Space Engineers, then you can expect frequent and awesome changes to come hard and fast.

DAY 1 Pros:
-Textures (even if placeholders) are beautiful and rich. The forest landscape reminds me of Elder Scrolls Oblivion.
-DirectX 11 and multithreading offer stability and  terrific multiplayer opportunities down the road.
-Destruction is very well designed and the physics seems solid.

Day 1 Cons:
-If the projectiles are the same mass and velocity to the eventual siege weapons, then stone walls will need to be a lot more durable, because right now they seem to be as strong as cardboard.
-No multiplayer or survival at day one. This is expected, but I just want it to be obvious if you are going to buy the game based on that.
-A distinct lack of goats.

Summary: Game has extremely high amounts of potential and is already fun to tinker about inside the world. Software company that makes it is very considerate of their players and will update frequently and deliver.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tried building a Catapult that throws rocks...
got a rock that throws a catapult 10/10

Serious review:

First thing first, If you love Space engineers and love medieval you will love this for sure!

Now this is like space engineers in early access whic means there will be bugs glitches and missing content,
As of today 12/2/15 the game Is REALLY gorgeous.
Im running on max settings with:
i7-3770 intel core
8gb ram
660 GTX card
and the game runs a nice 50-55~ frames 99% of the time for me

Pros:
+Awesome building potential
+Great Sound track
+Really good textures and nice atmosphere
+Nice physics and destruction (Atm since its early acess it isn't 100% good but when it does Oh boy does it make you feel good)
+Good optimization (from what I can tell as i have no frame drops)
+Workshop / mods

Cons:
-Early access might make people ignore it
-glitchy in some parts when trying to make physics based objects
-Long loading times (for me it takes 1-3 mins to load a level)
-The price Atm wont be worth for some people the amount of content

Neutral:
= Reused UI as space engineers
= Flying feels like you are in space
= there is no lighting to add to dark places (At the moment of writing this review)

Over all If you really like Space engineer you should get it
Its a real fun for every medieval fan.
If you don't like early access just wait for this and get it.
afraid of the price? wait for a drop

It is really got, but perfect but worth it in the end for the fans

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is an early access game so it's not anywhere near complete yet and what features it does have do have some glitches.  However, it gets updated every week and is already a lot of fun.  It satisfies 2 primal urges:  the need to build your own caslte, and the need to destroy castles.  Doesn't everybody want to do that?

Just don't get too attached to anything you make right now, or rely on mods, because it's quite likely, probably a certainty, that changes to the game will break your stuff on a regular basis.  But that's OK because they've got a lot of blocks to add still, and those will make your old stuff obsolete anyway.

So go ahead and get it.  You'll enjoy it.  Just be sure to read the help screen, watch the tutorials, watch user videos, and check the forums for help and solutions.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I typically don't do early access games but Keen Software is the exception to the rule. Space Engineers is one of the most well done early access games ever done and I expect no less from Medieval Engineers. I'm proud to be part of the development phase because this is the game I've dreamed of since I was a kid. The physics engine is amazing - very similar to what Red Faction: Guerrilla did years ago. The graphics are phenomenal and I cannot wait until day/night/weather cycles are added. A giant castle with the interior lit with torches is going to look incredible.

The game simply has loads of potential and I cannot wait to see what future updates will bring. Even at this point the game is worth it - base price of $20 for an incredible creative mode that simply no other game can offer.

What separates this game from Minecraft, Terraria, etc. is that the creations you make feel alive and anchored to real life physics. If there is too much weight on a column it will collapse. That is so cool and it's amazing so few games have even attempted this.

This game is recommended to anyone interested in the whole voxel/creation type genre or even those who have the slightest interest in Medieval tech/construction. Buy it, you won't regret the purchase.

EDIT: Please be aware there are some frustrating things in this game but it does not change my positive opinion/outlook on the title:

- Trees/bushes cannot be built over/removed - you have to shoot projectiles at them hoping not to destroy whatever creation is around them

- The mechanical pieces are very wonky - even basic catapults are very difficult to use

- If you make a mistake building with structural integrity on you have to wait a few minutes until the debris clears to rebuild. You can't manually remove debris

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Medieval Engineers is rough around the edges to be sure. It is buggy and there's not much to do, but I've already been impressed with the system at work. It's amazing how easy this game makes it to build really neat looking buildings. The real reason to buy this now is that 1) it's being developed by Keen Software House, whose regular updates to Space Engineers continue to bring out new potential in the game and 2) Keen has been known to raise the price of their games after sufficient updating.

I've had so much fun watching Space Engineers grow from an awkward, clunky alpha to the breathtaking thing that it is now and I'm excited to do the same with Medieval Engineers.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nKeen Software House is the best example of Early Access you can get! They keep in contact with the community. They make meaningful updates weekly. They are very honest and open about their plans and direction with the game, and best of all THEIR GAME WORKS! Medieval Engineers -- aside from some bugs and optimization -- is already at a state where they could go full release! The building mechanics are solid and it doesn't take long before you're making your dream castle! They give you enough tools to let your imagination run wild, especially the blocks within blocks tool! Compound blocks allows you to invent new blocks on the fly to suit your design, making you have that extra level of detail to any creatoin. The added structural integrity mode makes building feel more like a challenge. You have to be aware of how much weight is being placed on certain blocks. It adds an air of tension while you're building, Oh gosh will this block be the one to ruin my castle?" The game gets a new sense of tension in this mode and I love it for this! This game is a near perfect and its not even finished! Keep going Keen Software House! You are the reason for Early Access!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Keen Software House did it again, I thoroughly enjoy my time being spent with Medieval Engineers along with Space Engineers. the latter is spectacular and now this....... this just amazes me with all the potential it brings boys and girls.
Medivieval Engineers is a voxel based game with the newly added terriforming capabilities that gives the correct tools to bring ones gaming experience to a new level. build a castle, homestead, or reanimate landscapes that you could only dream of. The building is excellent with easy to use instructions and hotkeys, have four different sets of customeizable keys at your will to make what you please. I am eagerly waiting for the RELIABLE updates these guys bring and the loyal development they bring to the table(been here since SE launch). Keensoftware house builds games, communties, and friends without effert due to there hard earned ethics. if you second guess alpha launches or early acces develpment, there is nothing to worry about here, join in and have fun, watch this baby grow into a giant!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

- - - -I will update this review as the game updates. Most recent review update: 3/3/15- - - -

This game is incredible and exactly what I paid for. A game stressed upon physics that has near limitless capabilities, based upon construction, destruction, rinse and repeat. 8/10, but since it came out only a few days ago, I'd say it deserves those extra points for being this fantastic right from the get-go. If you want an awesome game, buy now. If you want a game you'll(or at least I'll) play for the rest of your life after a few months period of updates, Buy. Now. All in all, there are some drawbacks, but it's almost 98% positive fun gameplay. That is, if your Fun" includes architectural design and physics used to demolish everything in sight.

+Positive+
+Even the medium graphics are incredible. If you have a tough system
date: please play on the highest graphics possible
recommended: for the beauty of the scenery is astounding. +30 points\n+The physics engine is to DIE for. I've been craving a game of this caliber for my entire life. Want a bridge that splits in the middle and slides into sockets? Do it. Want a machine gun catapult? Do. It. Want a rope suspended bridge that rebounds against cannon balls? Do. +70 points\n+The versatility of what you can make is awe-inspiring. You could make a system of pulleys and winches that operates 20 catapults surrounding a castle to demolish it in one fell swoop(or alternatively
hoursPlayed: miss with every single one and destroy your beautiful catapults.). +40 points\n+Realizing what I've said earlier

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI'd like to point out that while I do have a AMD FX 8350 8 core clocked at 4.3Ghz, 32Gb RAM, the GTX 660 I have only has 2Gb video ram. Even on the lowest settings, I've had lagging issues. Mainly when objects break and fall. It's not little objects, it's the large number of objects that are in motion. The grass and flower animations are unaltered. Trees break fine without issues. It's when I smash stone walls or other thick and large objects. Other than that, the game is fun, but is better played with friends.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is a fun game that incorporates block based construction with voxel terrain editing. The limited initial lineup of blocks to build with has been balanced by the ability to merge blocks. The basic technology and small blocks also grant a lot of freedom in design. The developers have a good track record for content updates as well as listening to the community, so I am confident that this game will fill out well as it develops.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Played a little bit of this and the building is certainly fun, though getting used to the controls (especially ground leveling) takes a while to do. Impressive in the structures you can build in it, especially for an Early Access, and I'm sure it will continue to grow as features are added in.

That being said, the features I would very much like to see added:
-Gathering: We can knock down trees, but... do what with them?
-Planting: I'd like to be able to create a forest where I'd want it.
-Water (rivers/lakes): Seriously my biggest glaring issue was that the fields have no water. Castles are almost -never- built without a water supply nearby. Would like to be able to place springs to start river flows through channels. (I know this is a difficult one, fluid physics in a game tend to be the most difficult ones, but it feels like a dead world without it).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Played a little bit of this and the building is certainly fun, though getting used to the controls (especially ground leveling) takes a while to do. Impressive in the structures you can build in it, especially for an Early Access, and I'm sure it will continue to grow as features are added in.

That being said, the features I would very much like to see added:
-Gathering: We can knock down trees, but... do what with them?
-Planting: I'd like to be able to create a forest where I'd want it.
-Water (rivers/lakes): Seriously my biggest glaring issue was that the fields have no water. Castles are almost -never- built without a water supply nearby. Would like to be able to place springs to start river flows through channels. (I know this is a difficult one, fluid physics in a game tend to be the most difficult ones, but it feels like a dead world without it).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

- - - -I will update this review as the game updates. Most recent review update: 3/3/15- - - -

This game is incredible and exactly what I paid for. A game stressed upon physics that has near limitless capabilities, based upon construction, destruction, rinse and repeat. 8/10, but since it came out only a few days ago, I'd say it deserves those extra points for being this fantastic right from the get-go. If you want an awesome game, buy now. If you want a game you'll(or at least I'll) play for the rest of your life after a few months period of updates, Buy. Now. All in all, there are some drawbacks, but it's almost 98% positive fun gameplay. That is, if your Fun" includes architectural design and physics used to demolish everything in sight.

+Positive+
+Even the medium graphics are incredible. If you have a tough system
date: please play on the highest graphics possible
recommended: for the beauty of the scenery is astounding. +30 points\n+The physics engine is to DIE for. I've been craving a game of this caliber for my entire life. Want a bridge that splits in the middle and slides into sockets? Do it. Want a machine gun catapult? Do. It. Want a rope suspended bridge that rebounds against cannon balls? Do. +70 points\n+The versatility of what you can make is awe-inspiring. You could make a system of pulleys and winches that operates 20 catapults surrounding a castle to demolish it in one fell swoop(or alternatively
hoursPlayed: miss with every single one and destroy your beautiful catapults.). +40 points\n+Realizing what I've said earlier

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Medieval Engineers is extremely fun, especially for an early access game. There are plently of parts, moving and static, that you can build with and create contraptions out of. The controls are easy to learn, and the physics are spot on. Want to build a treuchet? Do it! Want to build a castle on top of a mountain? Go for it! Want to turn the world to rubble? Go ahead! The possibilities are endless, and it will keep you occupied for hours.

10/10 would shoot a barbarian off a cliff again

reviewText:
Early Access Review

All in all, this game has been a fantastic experience for what I have messed with so far. The destruction is crazy! A recent patch (as of writing this reveiw) has added the max fracture pieces option, allowing you to bump it up to a whopping 2048, meaning the destruction is even more detailed!

If you are an avid lover of sandbox/voxel construction games with a more serious approach to realism, I would pick this title up with no hesitation. I am one of the most indecisive people ever and I scooped this game without a second thought, and I did not regret it one bit. The developers are adding in great content with each patch and going above and beyond to make this game stand out from your tradiitonal voxel game.

PROS
+Beautiful graphics
+Detailed destruction system
+Infinite building possibilites
+Advanced structural integrity & Physics
+Dedicated Development team
+Barbarians!

CONS
-Slight lag on multiple collisions when hitting a build (fling lots of balls=lag)
-occasional glitches when winding/unwinding cranks

Overall, I give this game a solid 9/10. Improvements are steady and multi-player is going to be a blast!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A good building game, with realistic physics (most of the time) , a growing pallette of blocks to choose from, active updates and more! Although I have yet to really find the best ways to utilize the mechanism parts, I've had a blast making my first proper fortification, and look forward to what they bring out next. The pvp capabilities do seem a little limited, but with the addition of the crossbow it's definitely a lot more possible in the terms of the siege scenarios. Would recomend to any friend interested in building, while I would wait to alert those looking for pvp, aside from castle destruction.

*Pros
-Good selection of blocks
-Beautiful scenery
-Realistic physics and destruction
-Creative tools are a huge boon

*Cons
-Higher requirements limit the numbers during sieges
-Pvp isn't optimized, but on it's way

*Suggestions
-Team owned bots (Archers acting simmilar to the turrets perhaps?)
-Better gear system to optimize moving energy from power source (windmill) to mechanism (Gate / drawbridge / trap/ etc)

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAs of now the game is boring. I have attempted to claim a refund for over a year but steam won't let me get rid of it, so over time I have come back to it hoping I did not waste £15 on it. Turns out nothing has really changed, the game itself is nothing compared to Space Engineers and I feel that they only developed this games to test future aspects for Space Engineers. Don't get me wrong I like Space Engineers and Planets being one of the most game changing updates and I love it. But this just makes me sick. Survival is unplayable and creative is boring. Multiplayer just gets repetitive and also boring. I do not recommend buying this game in its current state, but there still could be something to come in the future. Well at least I hope there will be.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There has not been a substantial update in forever.  It feels like this game is in developement limbo, and with the lack of direction or anything that seems like an intended goal, I can't recommend this game.  It seemed very promising and fun at first, but given the fact that I bought it based off the potential of it---and how well they were doing with Space Engineers... I feel very burned by this game.  It seems like their Update Tuesdays" are a joke compared to the leaps Space Engineers used to take.

Want the same boring blocks over and over again?  How about in three colors!  Wood

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After the Space Engineers got tired of building,blowing up, and crashing their designs, they decided to warp back somewhere from the 5th to 15th century time periods. Now with MORE to destroy and a very impressive integrity software, the Space Engineers dubbed themselves.....The Medieval Engineers!


Okay now for what I think. With the new update out and all of the previous information I really enjoy Medieval Engineers. As I said the integrity software is VERY enjoyable. I've spent almost 1/2 my time watching large castles and trees fall with awing enviroment interaction. I look forward to every minute I invest into this new development by Keen Software!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You will get a bunch of people, many of which are barely literate, who will tell you that this game is a cash in. That the developers are pouring out unfinished games to get the moola. But I don't see this being the case, not while features are being implemented to both games to complement the development. People will tell you that this is the reason they half ♥♥♥♥♥ Space Engineers, but then again these people were the ones who took frequent updates for granted.

Though the game hasn't got too much, which was the case with SE, it is enjoyable if you enjoy building with an added challenge. The game allows you build out fantasy or medieval settings to your heart's content but with the fact these buildings must be constructed with structural integrity in mind.  Due to that system, the destruction of the buildings are incredibly satisfying... or heartbreaking, depending on what side of the wall you're on.  Not forgetting a pully system that puts your medieval engineering to the test with elaborate gates, mechanisms and siege weaponry.

The game has a lot of potential in the terms of PVP, Roleplay and Sandbox pleasure you might find in similar games. To say the least, they have added a fresh taste to this somewhat bloated genre. I just hope they make a decent survival element to it all.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Do you want to build castles, houses, towers, windmills, and other medieval structures? Get this game
Do you want to randomly destroy the things you built, by either just chucking boulders at things, or setting up catapults, etc?  Get this game
Do you want to essentially press x and activate your 'jetpack' in creative mode?  Get this game
Do you want to follow weekly updates from KSH and their awesome update system?  Get this game

All of that being said, this game is still very early access, there are a lot of things to be done.  There is no survival mode, but the things for it are essentially there, and you can see it all coming together.  You do not have to build on a plane if you wish not to, as there is a new dynamic construction mode.  Definite fun, especially with a friend, the possibilites are endless.  Ill be watching development closely to decide when to start a server.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is wonderful. Even in the current unpolished state, the game is addictive and hits a chord that few other games can hit. The destruction physics are entertaining and challenging. The desire to build is constantly driven by how big can I make this" and "how can I hit this with a cannonball and make it fall". As features continue to expand
date: I expect to see this game become a wonderful gem of the gaming world.\n\nI would disreguard most of the negative reviews on here because they seem to have missed the point that this game is in extremely early stages. For it to function as it does with the minimal bugs and issues is very impressive. As well
recommended: the dev team is extremely invested and dedicated to giving the community what they want. The collaborations between the Medieval and Space engineers devs is something of a golden goose. Expect to see a lot of wonderful new content in Space Engineers as well as ME. If you are truly interested in this game
voteText: support the devs now and save yourself some cash. You won't regret it.\n\n(Also disreguard the lack of hours as I have been extremely busy and haven't been able to play as much as I wish.)"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I do reccomend this game;
in it's current state (just been released) you can already mod the game and it has full workshop support.

The developers are one of the best there has been for quite some time, if the community really wants a particular update, the developers will add it, the next thursday. Currently you can build catapults and trubuchets and drawbridges and anything else you can come up with that is mechanical and involving wieghts, ropes and rotating wood.

The destruction is also very nice, the block crumble into chunks and look very pretty.  the game overall looks very pretty in fact. And, if you have played KSHs other game: space engineers, you will know how satisfying it is to build an impressive contraption or building and know that it works.

However, It is still a little glitchy (a lot of the glitches can be sorted by youself very easily (a whole bunch were fixed in the last patch). The game runs fairly well and if you can't, the graphics presets, while basic, do offer a decent change in performance at each stage.

Overall, This game is definately reccomended by me, and if it is updated as frequently as space engineers is (the developers have promised they will) then this game could become a favourite for many.
