reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nwell I bought and installed it lastnight, and I was kinda discouraged by the slow pace and odd building style so I turned the game off and went and watched some movies. Later on I turned it back on just to give it another try before I think about the waste of money I am going to uninstall like so many others. That's when we (me and the game) just clicked, something magical happened that lured me in, and now 5 hours later at 5am I have a giant castle wall a very nice farmhouse with horse stables and a working windmill... As of now I don't want to put the game down but I have to go to sleep for work in the afternoon. The game itself doesn't have much to it as of yet, no NPC's, no multiplayer, no sort of interaction at all. But what it does have is beautiful graphics, sweet mechanics, good ole fashioned creative mode with quite a few different starter maps, and the ability to teraform entire mountains or sling cannonballs at whatever creation you make (or the provided premade buildings). Pick it up while it's on sale, it's well worth the price, heck I'd even pay full price for it because I've seen the hard work the devs have put into Space Engineers and I'm sure this one's going to come along nicely.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've only played this for Half an hour and I'm already becoming addicted to this game.

Pros:
+ The building mechanics are awesome.
+ Destruction is amazing.
+ Soundtrack is just gorgeous.
+ Graphics are really well done.
+ Physics are epic.

Cons
-  Some graphical errors (You'll expect that from an early access game)
- The red box whilst building gets in the way a lot.
- Placing wood is a bit fiddly

Overall:
I found the game to be very enjoyable and after a hard day of College, I can't wait to sink my teeth into some more of this amazing game. I'll be editing this review overtime when either some of the cons have been fixed or improved upon or if I find some more errors.

Final Verdict:

9.5/10
Buy it!

However, It is still a little glitchy (a lot of the glitches can be sorted by youself very easily (a whole bunch were fixed in the last patch). The game runs fairly well and if you can't, the graphics presets, while basic, do offer a decent change in performance at each stage.

Overall, This game is definately reccomended by me, and if it is updated as frequently as space engineers is (the developers have promised they will) then this game could become a favourite for many.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Truly enjoyable constructing game, I have enjoyed SE some 20 odd hours and found this to be more to my taste. Structural integrity is fun to toy around with and can make a serious impact on your build if you don't take it into consideration. I tried to make a huge stone floor, that was about 600+ blocks in total, in one go. And the whole thing collapsed and broke since it was only supported on 2 corners. Looking forward to more content and community mods, because this baby got some serious potential to shine.

So if you enjoy to explore mechanics, build castles, build siege engines and medival contraptions, to toy around with physics and general engineering, I say give it a go.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Medieval Engineers is absolutely beautiful and Keen is a developer that follows through on continuous updates and listening to the community.
Unfortunately, right now I wouldn't recommend this game.  There's just not much going on (vanilla version, which I base reviews off of).  You want to build a castle? great.  You want derpy servants that might actually be up to par with medieval intelligence?  Also yes.  Do you want contraptions that actually make sense in a physics based environment?  Maybe someday.
For now it's all about the looks and sadly its mechanical blocks fall short of even minecrafts simplistic design.
Still, I have faith in Keen and will be glad to change this review to a plus after a few updates which add real content.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The soundtrack is really what makes or breaks a game; this is one of those games that the music is phenominal. It has the nostalgic feel of medieval styled instruments, and never before has it felt so epic to build and explore. I can't help but compare this to Minecraft; the building is extensive and entertaining, as Minecraft very well achieved, however this game has the music that makes the game brilliant. Not too much content so far, but I'm sure in a couple months it's gonna be stock full with content.
The graphics aren't too bad; they have a Skyrim like feel to them and the scenery looks gorgeous even on low. The game isn't really optimised yet, destroying walls makes my graphics lag. I have a decent graphics card and I hope that the game will get optimisation.
What's even better is this is coming from a developer that you can trust; Space Engineers has been out for about a year and every week there's still updates coming out. Just to reassure those who believe that now that this game has come out, Space Engineers is abandoned; that is false. The company who brought you the Engineers games have two teams working on both of the games, each meritting the same style of great game. These 'Engineers' games have been an interesting expirience for I know not just me, but for thousands, if not millions of people worldwide.
***Review is Subject to Change***
9/10
Nice graphics
Minimal bugs
Great interface
Fantastic scenery
Brilliant gameplay

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I just played medieval engineers, and decided to write this review even though I played only few houres in the game.
The game is amazing .
Here are some good and bad points that I think it is importent to give them a try  :

Good:

1) demolition amazing animation and fun. (There is nothing more fun than destroying stuff you built).
2) stunning graphics.
3) the possible construction areas, which require creativity and great design (because the laws of physics can be found in the game, not just so building, which adds a challenge and fun).

Bad:

1) The game takes a long time to to be loaded.
2) The ground editor very uncomfortable, and very unfriendly to new players.
3) The voice of the barbarians annoying .. would be great if it would be possible to change the sound or mute the barbarians in particular.

To improve:
I noticed a couple of things I would love if repaired or will be added to the game.
1)I think it would be great if you feel the possibility of Ctrl + Z so that we can correct mistakes we made.
2) I think that could be great if the world would be added flat type, so that it can be built on a flat surface without shape the surface of the earth.
3) Would be great if added to the tool which can erase the ruins. It's quite annoying that you can not delete ruins and each time build a castle tower and he falls to start the game again and build it all again. (I must say that it makes the construction of a castle feel pretty stressful thing).

In conclusion, a great game.
The game can provide hours and hours of building castles and weapons medieval building demolition, careful planning of buildings.
Would be great if he could contain multiplayer game, or at least co-op so that it can be done wars or joint construction (similar to space engineers).
Highly recommanded , Buy it now !!
11 \ 10!

*by the way  , I apologize for my poor English . Thank you for reading my review :D

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The early release is amazing. There are a few obvious bugs to be scratched quickly but so far this game is already amazing. Unlike Space Engineers I hope this game will become more of a multiplayer survival base game instead of just the space simulator that Space Engineers has been recently. The breaking is amazing and the integrety makes me a little wet but I just hope it doesn't all go to waste and become one of those games I play if I say I wonder if I can..." rather than a game where I can say "Lets get on a server and make a castle I can defend!"

I guess my point here is that space engineers is big on making things never seen with the tools at hand and while I love that about it I hope this game will be playable in survival strongly enough that there will be servers with average players that just want to build and be in a community.

Oh btw
date: 10/10 for an early release. If you enjoy destroying large building that took hours to build you're either going to love it a lot or hate it a lot depending on wether or not you meant to destroy it."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hello this is a M-DAWG early access review I will change it constantly in the coming months so where i have marked (early access common problem) means that it will inveitably be fixed.

First let me start by putting the definiton of Early Access ... twice (For the mentally stunted people among us)

Early access, alphafunding, or paid-alpha is a funding model in the video game industry by which consumers can pay for a game in the early stages of development and obtain access to playable but unfinished versions of the game, while the developer is able to use those funds to continue work on the game.

Early access, alphafunding, or paid-alpha is a funding model in the video game industry by which consumers can pay for a game in the early stages of development and obtain access to playable but unfinished versions of the game, while the developer is able to use those funds to continue work on the game.


As can see i've spent about 45 minutes on ME and already am getting the hang of it, please watch the tutorial it seems long- being 15 minutes but it will save you hours of time later on.ME is a strange beast, me wanting to see the full potential of the game I kept the building realism on as i was building my classic four sided with turrets and a drawbridge castle I was punched in the stomach by my walls collapsing and falling into rubble.Please don't quit the game and then let it sit in your steam library, put your chin up and try again- this time with supports and maybe smaller walls-make your design simpler you can always make it more complex in the future.

A funny story:
This is a really nice table let me have a close *ragdoll time* BLURRRRRRGHSMASHBONKOHNOBANG... oh.. my house is gone.

Pro's:
Great Potential!
Realistic!
So much to do!
Great dev support!

Cons:
Can be clunky at sometimes :( (Early Access common problem)
Can lag at destruction more optimization needed :( (Early Access common problem)
Stuff can break and go weird:(


Things (opinions)
Lack of content (IF YOUR GOING TO BUY A FLIPPIN EARLY ACCESS GAME DON'T HAVE A GO AT THE DEVS FOR LACK OF CONTENT- Same way don't go up to an artist thats displaying underfinished work and tell them that it doesn't have much detail.

Verdict:
This is a good question I can only do one of those chart thingys

1.Do you like castles and all that sort of stuff
A. Yes
B. No

If B WHARRRTTT ARE YOU DOING HERE.
If a carry on

2.Do you enjoy putting a lot of time into a game - learning, building
a. Yes
b. No

If b you are the plague of this *cough* don't buy it

If a carry on


3.Do you understand WHAT ♥♥♥♥ING EARLY ACCESS MEANS
A.yes
B.No

B GO AND BUY A CONSOLE YOU ♥♥♥♥ING PHILISTINE

A. This world is your oyster GO BUILD MY BROTHER/SISTER

Overall a great start for what could turn out to be a classic game!

I hope some certain intelligent people will take my information and use it to choose wether they will or will not buy this game.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is a reskinned Space Engineers, no doubt about it. But I'm honestly impressed. In just an hour of play I can tell you this game is worth $15. The textures are strikingly beautiful, the building is currently decent with much room for growth, and you can tell that this game will get to be pretty all-around excellent with a bit of love and a lot of added content. Your current options as of now are to build and destroy--and the latter is pretty damn fun. You have no way of actually repairing things yet, like you can in SE. Physics is excellent; object destruction appears very real. I'm interested in seeing mining, refining, and other SE-type properties imported medieval-style.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Point #1. Alpha
Point #2. Awesome
Point #3. Keen Software House. These guys (and Gals) know how to properly rock the Engineer Moustache. = Double Awesome Power. DAP Status confirmed.

Warning: Lengthy review of shenaniganz incoming.

On a more serious note, about the game. Ahh the game. Structural integrity, so awesome while still inflicting fear and terror upon all engineers endeavoring on massive projects. You must think about your structures and gadgets with gravity in mind. It will destroy what you have worked so hard to build, and when it doesnt, when you have built not only a beautiful machine or structure, You have also built a structural masterpiece. Every support, each minor detail, Every stress point in your Project must be carefully managed and at times avoided. This game will make you or break you. It will wittle you down over the hours of time you spend on a single large scale project, you can make an error in your projects design only to realize it later, after you have built your monument to your ingenuity. Be careful my fellow Engineers, Gravity was once our ally in deep space. Now it is our enemy. Now quit screwin around and buy this game already. If not for Keens DAP status, then for Engineerings sake!



Ok. Actually serious now.
Keen Software House reminds me of a company I knew and loved some time ago. They are honest, they care about their games. They care about what we say and we say alot (obviously /\ ). I would not have bought this game the day it came on alpha if I did not trust in its developers. I have played Space Engineers, I was not dissapointed by the game itself, and found myself surprised and thoroughly impressed by its Development team. I have faith that Keen Software House will not disappoint.

The game.
The game is in alpha as of this moment. There is no multiplayer at this time(May change in the near future). The graphics of the game leave it at a stage of simple beauty. The mechanics of the game are operational, I say operational  for there is still some fine tuning to be done however that is expected, Medieval Engineers is still in alpha stage. I personally enjoy building projects that are effected by the world surrounding it. If you enjoy minecraft, but feel a need for some realism, this game is perfect for you. There will be plenty of mods down the road, trust me. I suggest you buy the game now, enjoy it while you can, save it for later if the lack of multiplayer is a huge turn off and just keep up to date with the games progress as time passes. You can thank me later (and the Dev team. Love you guys! xD )

i honestly bought this for the sole reason of throwing money at these wonderful devs. They have never let me down, and I don't belive they ever would. I have written one example of their impecable service below.


Alright so heres the story:

I had a world Literature class.
The class required a group project.
I chose to do a Machinima.
I rounded up a couple of Irish Guys I play ArmA with and set to work.
We used Space Engineers
I build 2 massive castles and all the props, space-fighters and battle cruisers
We took the Story of Perceval and butchered it to make it Perceval in space.
Putting a medieval story in a space-age setting went about as well as that Family guy cut away about MacBeth in Space.

3 months later Keen Releases Medieval Engineers.

Moral of the story? Keen will always deliver to you exactly what you need... They'll just be comedically late as if their trolling you.

10/10 would fail Lit Class again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

!!!EARLY ACCESS REVIEW!!!
Even in it's current state, the developer's have put in a huge amount of work into this. Fully destructible structures that allow people to admire what we have been longing for for decades in the gaming industry (excluding the Red Faction series)

The construction engine in this game allows for some rather unique and powerful designs to be born from the players mind. Although rather complicated to get everything working as the construction uses a lot of different parts to come to life, once accomplished things such as trebuchet's that launch wooden poles which the player has to put in can be fired, catapult's can be made with counter-weight's, an entire village and a castle on a hill can be made, fort's with their own defences and human-activated bridges can be built to grant passage between a bridge, a gap and the fort itself, even a car can be made! But that's not counted as it's due to the player having super-human powers =T

I have so far only been able to make a poopy little immobile light catapult that launches a single boulder, but I have seen people on the youtube's build catapults that fire 5 or more different boulders! Of course, without the proper craftsmanship required to build such a thing, it will break due to physics and weight affecting everything.

The destruction in this game is also astonishing! Being able to crumble structures in a way that I have never seen before really makes me want to continue playing this game. Being able to watch a humongous chunk of stone fall off the top of a tower and crumble a tichy little house beneath it just makes me want to keep replaying that moment at different angles and analyse how awesome it all looks! Of course, everything breaks at given points, but it looks so dynamic and realistic you probably won't notice that for the first hour or two of playing the game because you'll be too into destroying everything and watching how neatly everything crumbles and cracks and breaks around the point of impact!

The only current downside to the game for me is the flying. It feels too much like Space Engineers gravity-less flying and the momentum kind of gets annoying too. I personally like to fly around like in Garry's Mod, move when you want to move, stop when you want to stop. Other than that it's a very useful feature.

The graphics in this game are also really nice. They have a realistic medieval feel to them and actually look like what they are supposed to be. Stone looks like actual stone, wood looks like wood, ceramic roofs look a bit too modern, but I guess they can also be seen as Roman roofs if you would like to think of them in that way. The trees (which can also be broken and knocked over) look like really nice trees. The only thing so far that makes my computer want to go super saiyan is when the entire castle map which can be pre-loaded is destroyed and the rubble is moving. Apart from that, the game (at least on my intermediate powered PC) runs very smoothly at 40+ fps.


So, TL;DR?
Amazing game, brilliant and realistic physics, awesome construction engine, runs smoothly, good graphics and has an awesome soundtrack!


720/10
Would definitely chuck boulders like the Hulk into castles from different angles and simulate people screaming in fear again

Early Access Review

Can't really do a full review on a product like Medieval Engineers yet as it’s still in Early Alpha. That being said, the game shows great promise from the get go! I won’t lie to you there are still a lot of bugs and certain things don’t seem to work right but all in all it is very good at this stage. Although I’m really enjoying this game so far there does seem to be a lot of lag for me. Admittedly my computer isn't ''Beast'' but I can run space engineers perfectly on high/ ultra-settings. My experience so far has been mixed but i have still enjoyed it therefore this review is subject to change. xD

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been counting the hours for this to release, and with it out now i am very satisfied.

some of the pros;

+Very Visually appealing
+plenty of parts to suit for now
+The structural integrity feature is really spot on, not so weak that you cant build anything without a collapse and not so strong you cant break it.
+UI is based off Space engineers which is really a good setup
+super smooth access to workshop whether publishing or downloading
A few cons;

-Rotation is a pain
-some items have no weight or integrity unless you turn them on, so if you furnish and entire castle and then the beds and torches and chests wont fall with it cause your forgot to switch, it can be a lil frustrating
-every now and again things don't fall right, not often though
-catapulting is odd sometimes due to the machine randomly starting to gyrate or jerk around, or break. This is rare though
-No Trebuchet yet :(
-Needs more Gears and machinary

Obviously most negatives are going to get fixed or patched or parts added, but this is the current standing and even still with the cons present, it is super fun, and i love this game so much, i cant wait to see it bloom into a masterpiece

reviewText:
Early Access Review

To be perfectly honest this game is one of my favorite games, It was JUST released and already it has an amazing building system, experimental AI and great destruction. The physics are a bit jenky but what can you expect from such an early game. One other problem I have is you can't rotate certain blocks upsidedown or sideways. There is no multiplayer as of yet but as I said before it was just released.


The graphics are awesome and you should find no trouble running the game on medium (From my experience).


You can edit the terrain using a nice voxel system and even make structures with it.


You can build massive and beautiful structures with the even the basic blocks you have currently.


Next I should talk about the mechanical machines side of Medieval Engineers.


When searching for blocks to use you will find some mechanical bits and bobs, some of those are wheels, rope wheels, weight blocks and wooden rods (And more stuff besides). With this stuff you can build primitive vehicles, elevators, catapults and trebuchets!


I have not tested or even looked at the AI in game yet but so far they have been a success to everyone.


Overall I would say 8.3.2.0.7/10 if I were a critic, however I'm not one so really that personal score is irrelevant. You should decide whether or not you enjoy the game yourself and buy it :)


The people behind SE and now ME need to be hugged for making both games and if you enjoy this game buy Space Engineers or vice versa!


It's worth it.

No multiplayer yet, though.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hello this is a M-DAWG early access review I will change it constantly in the coming months so where i have marked (early access common problem) means that it will inveitably be fixed.

First let me start by putting the definiton of Early Access ... twice (For the mentally stunted people among us)

Early access, alphafunding, or paid-alpha is a funding model in the video game industry by which consumers can pay for a game in the early stages of development and obtain access to playable but unfinished versions of the game, while the developer is able to use those funds to continue work on the game.

Early access, alphafunding, or paid-alpha is a funding model in the video game industry by which consumers can pay for a game in the early stages of development and obtain access to playable but unfinished versions of the game, while the developer is able to use those funds to continue work on the game.


As can see i've spent about 45 minutes on ME and already am getting the hang of it, please watch the tutorial it seems long- being 15 minutes but it will save you hours of time later on.ME is a strange beast, me wanting to see the full potential of the game I kept the building realism on as i was building my classic four sided with turrets and a drawbridge castle I was punched in the stomach by my walls collapsing and falling into rubble.Please don't quit the game and then let it sit in your steam library, put your chin up and try again- this time with supports and maybe smaller walls-make your design simpler you can always make it more complex in the future.

A funny story:
This is a really nice table let me have a close *ragdoll time* BLURRRRRRGHSMASHBONKOHNOBANG... oh.. my house is gone.

Pro's:
Great Potential!
Realistic!
So much to do!
Great dev support!

Cons:
Can be clunky at sometimes :( (Early Access common problem)
Can lag at destruction more optimization needed :( (Early Access common problem)
Stuff can break and go weird:(


Things (opinions)
Lack of content (IF YOUR GOING TO BUY A FLIPPIN EARLY ACCESS GAME DON'T HAVE A GO AT THE DEVS FOR LACK OF CONTENT- Same way don't go up to an artist thats displaying underfinished work and tell them that it doesn't have much detail.

Verdict:
This is a good question I can only do one of those chart thingys

1.Do you like castles and all that sort of stuff
A. Yes
B. No

If B WHARRRTTT ARE YOU DOING HERE.
If a carry on

2.Do you enjoy putting a lot of time into a game - learning, building
a. Yes
b. No

If b you are the plague of this *cough* don't buy it

If a carry on


3.Do you understand WHAT ♥♥♥♥ING EARLY ACCESS MEANS
A.yes
B.No

B GO AND BUY A CONSOLE YOU ♥♥♥♥ING PHILISTINE

A. This world is your oyster GO BUILD MY BROTHER/SISTER

Overall a great start for what could turn out to be a classic game!

I hope some certain intelligent people will take my information and use it to choose wether they will or will not buy this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The current game development model is releaseing a very early vision of a game the developer wishes to make.  By giving early access, the developers can use the feedback from players throughout development to shape the game into something much greater.

Keen Software House delivers.  Based on their work with Space Engineers, the weekly patches are more than just bug fixes, but they truely bring new content.

Medieval Engineers is a great idea with lots of potential.  I look forward to the coming months and hopefully years of fun that this game has to offer.

Early Access Review

i can reccomend this, but i have a few downsides to point out:
Pros:
Castles
Catapults
smaking barbarians from very high places
Cons:
Bad combat mechanics
need a beefy computer to run
physics engine needs a sort of lag proofing (in castle seige i kept dieing due to clipping into the machines)
Toll range needs fixing or the graphic needs to be fixed (either one would do so that when im trying to break somthing down i can tell if im hitting it or not)

EDIT: Another notable glitch is where in castle seige you sometimes faze out of existance completely. this is a game-breaking glitch that should be fixed as soon as possible. Also, this glitch
makes it to where you cant type, respawn, or even move your camera.


Anyways, im reccomending it because its early access, and the devs have not yet sorted out everything, so the cons (or atleast most of them) are acceptable, for the moment at least.

***DON'T BUY THIS IF YOU'RE ON WINDOWS 10 AND HAVE AN NVIDIA BASED GRAPHICS CARD.***
I would love to write a positive review of this game... But I can't. I wouldn't be posting a technical issue as a poor review, BUT this particular bug has been around for over a month at least, and the work around involving Windows 10 and nVidia graphics card drivers (that's not really posted or documented well) is to DOWNGRADE your drivers to a specific range. This bug does not affect the game's sister product, Space Engineers, so I'm scratching my head at this one.

I will change this review IF AND WHEN they address the graphics problems for nVidia cards.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Being co-developed at the same time as Space Engineers, one would think the premise would work in medeival times as also, but it just doesn't. Many features are still missing, which is okay because it is still in development, but the real issue is with the interface. It was bad in Space Engineers, but workable. In this, it just doesn't work (at least not with flying turned off.) Building up requires getting pretty creative with scaffolding type parts or jumping between blocks (don't fall off or you will be stuck trying to cobble together some type of stairway.) Once resource requirements are implemented, this is going to be a real issue.

Figuring out how all the parts work together is interesting, challenging, and frankly downright frustrating sometimes, again due to the shoddy interface. The game looks beautiful at least.

I would love to recommend this title as I really enjoy the idea of being able to build freely, but with the clunky interface and the current lack of working features, I just can't recommend it at this time. Maybe in the future it will be a different story.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIts gotten a lot of hate lately, and I can understand why. Survival is unplayable at the moment, the physics are a bit buggy, playing online is buggy as all hell, and the progress is very slow. I would call it a reskin of space engineers though, I kinda like the controls on this game a bit more than space engineers, and think they could do well from some more similarities in building controls. All I ever really do is build ♥♥♥♥ and ♥♥♥♥ around, I've even made a car powered by gears and the handle wheel thingy. It does need much improvement, and its demanding in pc specs for some, but I'd say for people who like building, its a good buy when on sale.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Patiently waited til 4PM to get game.
Waited another two hours after the release was pushed back, watched michael rosen in the meantime.
Bought at 25% off, fantastic.
Downloaded in under 15 minutes, really good.
Launched game while stuffing a great big load of plums into my mouth.
Changed to high settings, and user interface vanished.
After many tries to change to high settings, I decided to just create a game and get on with it.
Created custom game, and clicked OK...
Loading screen.
After a minute, the cog stops turning, and game crashes.
OH NO, THE MOMENT I DREAD WHEN THE GAME CRASHES.
11/10 would play again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is one of those sideways thumb reviews. It is fun to build cities and different kinds of machinery, but that is all you can really do at this time in the game. Sure, there is a survival mode but it is clunky and horribly balanced (survial aspect just is not ready yet, simply).

The weekly updates have been very minmal for a long time now. It is starting to seem like this was just means for Space Engineers funding (for now at least).

TLDR: Extremely slow development, only buy if you really like medieval building. + great soundtrack

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The only very specific feature about this game that has/had plagued Space Engineers for a long time is the Multiplayer netcode. It's quite spastic, jittery, and can be totally out to lunch some times. If you design things by your self you have no issue, it's when you bring your pieces of work into some one elses game that these issues occur. I've read that optimization is key on their list for both games, as the code for both are very similar. Still, if you were planning on having a massive battle with a bunch of friends, you may want to hold off at the moment. But they do recognize very much that these games aren't that fun to play alone.

I highly recommend this game, if you think you'd like this game, I'm almost positive you'll end up loving this game. And if it may be lacking a feature you desire, purchase it on sale and wait!

While I haven't nearly as many hours playing this as Space Engineers, I will tell you that this a very great game if you at all enjoyed space engineers, or particularly building stuff in minecraft. The game comes in it's current state in 3 base modes; Creative, Survival, and Castle Siege.

Keen Software House has done a lot in the past with space engineers to support modders and actually develope features that their player base asks for as well so you need not worry about the games turning into 'vapourware' or alike.

This game differs quite a bit from Space Engineers as you probably are assuming from the title, though core key layouts are pretty much the same between both games, so if you already have played space engineers you don't need to relearn much. They do have quite a different build system then other crafting games, and isn't exactly the most intuitive off the bat, though it doesn't take overly long to master.

Besides the Voxel/Morphable terrain, the physics is probably the most impressive feature. I'm not exactly sure how it works but it seems to crack entire models pretty well, giving immediate results to specific areas of impact. You can also customize how much physics debris you want loaded/calculated per server, which is quite nice. If you have an extremely powerful processor, I'm sure you could build Minas Tirth from LOTR and bring the whole thing down starting with the base of it.

The game does also support Melee and crossbow combat, though it's very basic at the moment and mostly just contains the core mechanics of fighting, the animations and AI can be quite lacking at least in the current state of review, as well I didn't dive deep into it, but is a feature that is fairly fun.

If you see this on sale and are the 'builder' or 'creative' type, I'd just throw caution to the wind and pick this up. When I first bought Space Engineers I didn't play it for probably 2 months, then fell in love when they added minable resources and ore processing.

There's already so much garbage on steam stores already, this is one item at $10.99 will not be a future regret.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Honestly, i was excited when i hear about it, but since its been out, ive been addicted, even with the little content block wise and workshop items, creations are endless, Now we can create any medieval RPG in whatever way we want, for as long and as big as we want.

This game is a Masterpiece,

.::: July Update :::.


..... Yup, still as awesome as it was before, it just got even better!


.::: September Update :::.

I still cant find anything i agree with in this game,i have especially enjoyed some of the little sneak previews the developers, have either intentionally left into the game for us to find, or just by accident, but from these we can see just how much detail is going to get put into the game. So far i have sumbled upon a number of unique player Skins, which include:

Female Engineer Models
Children Player /NPC Models
Old Man" Player /NPC Model

And new forms of hostile animals to be introduced into the world including the "Medieval Wolf"

Ive found all of these inside the Small chest ingame while using Creative
date: and after every update i now lov to go and check it out incase there's something new in there which could possibly tell us whats coming next.\n\nWith previews like this it leaves the door open for more things to be created such as: Plate Armour
voteText: Maces and Fails
helpfulPercent: it is essentially endless
votesHelpful: and with the annoucement of "Brain AI" this could protentally become of the most advanced Player NPC Interaction game out there.\n\nAs for the building
votesTotal: its only got better and more stable as its progressed
votesFunny: and now through their weeks up bugfixing the game is getting even smoother
commentsCount:

I can only hope that one day the developers will bring out large maps one day which will allow players to build kingdoms together through continous generation.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Medieval Engineers has enormous potential. At the moment, there are 3 different types of game modes. If you are in to building or destruction, creative is definitely for you. Every week they add new content, currently mostly for the new Survival game mode. If you like a challenge, and building impenetrable fortresses similar to games like ARK: Survival Evolved or Rust, then this mode could be for you. Its currently in heavy developement along with the rest of the game, and changes often. They are still adding construction models for blocks from Creative into Survival. However, building in this mode takes a long time and a lot of grinding for resources. Although its very fun to do so, it can be a bit time consuming. Last, but not least, is Castle Seige mode. If you are into seiging castles and love combat, this mode is for you. Despite the game's horrible combat system (Early Access), the invaders are supplied with seige weapons which are much more effective than player combat. This mode is made up of 2 teams, attackers and defenders.

Over all, the game is great. However, its very sad that the game is not as popular as I'd hoped for it to be. With more players, servers could be a lot more popular (currently most servers are empty) for more of an enjoyable experience in multiplayer. I think it would be quite amazing to create a castle and defend against raiders in a survival PVP server. I can only hope they keep making the game better and players keep joining in on the fun.

8/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The only very specific feature about this game that has/had plagued Space Engineers for a long time is the Multiplayer netcode. It's quite spastic, jittery, and can be totally out to lunch some times. If you design things by your self you have no issue, it's when you bring your pieces of work into some one elses game that these issues occur. I've read that optimization is key on their list for both games, as the code for both are very similar. Still, if you were planning on having a massive battle with a bunch of friends, you may want to hold off at the moment. But they do recognize very much that these games aren't that fun to play alone.

I highly recommend this game, if you think you'd like this game, I'm almost positive you'll end up loving this game. And if it may be lacking a feature you desire, purchase it on sale and wait!

While I haven't nearly as many hours playing this as Space Engineers, I will tell you that this a very great game if you at all enjoyed space engineers, or particularly building stuff in minecraft. The game comes in it's current state in 3 base modes; Creative, Survival, and Castle Siege.

Keen Software House has done a lot in the past with space engineers to support modders and actually develope features that their player base asks for as well so you need not worry about the games turning into 'vapourware' or alike.

This game differs quite a bit from Space Engineers as you probably are assuming from the title, though core key layouts are pretty much the same between both games, so if you already have played space engineers you don't need to relearn much. They do have quite a different build system then other crafting games, and isn't exactly the most intuitive off the bat, though it doesn't take overly long to master.

Besides the Voxel/Morphable terrain, the physics is probably the most impressive feature. I'm not exactly sure how it works but it seems to crack entire models pretty well, giving immediate results to specific areas of impact. You can also customize how much physics debris you want loaded/calculated per server, which is quite nice. If you have an extremely powerful processor, I'm sure you could build Minas Tirth from LOTR and bring the whole thing down starting with the base of it.

The game does also support Melee and crossbow combat, though it's very basic at the moment and mostly just contains the core mechanics of fighting, the animations and AI can be quite lacking at least in the current state of review, as well I didn't dive deep into it, but is a feature that is fairly fun.

If you see this on sale and are the 'builder' or 'creative' type, I'd just throw caution to the wind and pick this up. When I first bought Space Engineers I didn't play it for probably 2 months, then fell in love when they added minable resources and ore processing.

There's already so much garbage on steam stores already, this is one item at $10.99 will not be a future regret.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is everything I wanted from 'Minecraft' but couldn't get.  At the moment I'm engaged in the Castle building rather than the machine construction.  I can see the potential for future pieces and blocks - and once the modding community gets going the buildings will be fabulous (rather than just great).
The placing of blocks can be a struggle sometimes and even with update .008 the lighting is a real pain.  It's as if the devs are trying to be too clever by putting in day/night, sun position etc before fixing the awful shadow problems.  The interior lighting still needs a lot of work.
However, it is still early access and apart from the lighting problems this game is well on the way to getting 5 stars and being my favourite.

and now when you go in survival... damn thats another ♥♥♥♥.... is really really dificult to build. its even more dificult to get the resorces close to where you are building... i dont like the idea of the character does not have a cargo capacity..
dont take me wrong i like the game and i am actually gonna play it more... but it will be on a future... after some updates have pass.

I recomendend it has potencial, but for the moment just asume there is just creative.... forget about casual

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nits gr8 and all but rly. wtf is wrong with the physics. i was building a gate. it was a nice gate. a normal castle gate. see to build one i had to put down wooden blocks on the ground so it would stand up and i could build without it falling all over the place. however, for the gate to actually pull up and open, after i was done building i had to remove these...reinforcement blocks (lack of a better term). however, due to this game's messed up physics, after i removed these blocks for my gate to actually work, the gate went flying everywhere and ruined the whole thing. ♥♥♥♥ing fix this bs

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Medieval Engineers is one of the most enjoyable sandbox games since Space Engineers and Minecraft. There are a wide variety of things you can do while playing this game, including, but not limited to:

Building castles and houses.
Cutting down trees.
Mining stone.
Ruling like a king.
Being a deer.
With more features coming as time passes, I can expect this game to shape up to become a new benchmark in voxel-based sandbox titles. Bugs are present as always, but the developers are ironing them out with each new update.

Recommended to anyone who has played and enjoyed Space Engineers or anyone who likes building castles.
